moduleGroup.name: Automatic Tissue Classification v2
moduleGroup.description: This workflow takes raw un-skull-stripped volumes and generates tables of the total, GM, WM and CSF volumes.

dataModule.name: Atlas Specification File
dataModule.description: This is the Atlas specification file provided. There are 11 files to choose from. Select one of the files.

output.name: Output
output.description: This is the Atlas specification file provided. There are 11 files to choose from. Select one of the files.

module.name: SVPASEG
module.description: Brain tissue classification based on local Markov random fields and ICM algorithm..

input.name: Input image file
input.description: Enter the MRI T1 image that is to be segmented.

input.name: Maskfile
input.description: Enter the Maskfile of the brain without the skull. This will be used to perform skull stripping. All voxels with the value greater than 0.5 (in the mask) are assumed to belong to the brain.

input.name: Atlasfile
input.description: This is the atlas specification file.

input.name: fmmparamfile
input.description: A mixture parameters file. Misture parameter file must match the atlas specification file.

input.name: Unsigned
input.description: Specifying this option will assume that the data is unsigned.

input.name: Beta1
input.description: Regularization parameter first first-order interactions, defaults depend on particular model setting. It is NOT recommended to change the defaults.

input.name: Beta2
input.description: Regularization parameter for second order interactions i.e. controls the strenght of the spatial regularization component. Defaults to 0.05

input.name: PVElabels
input.description: Controls whether intermediate PVE classification labels are written, not relevant except for p-type atlases.

output.name: Labelfile
output.description: This is the tissue classified image (only pure tissue types).

module.name: Gamixture
module.description: Used for fitting the Finite Mixture Model to the image data using the genetic algorithms.
module.tag: FMM Finite Mixture Model Genetic algorithm

input.name: Input image file
input.description: Enter the MRI T1 image that is to be segmented.

input.name: Maskfile
input.description: Enter the Maskfile of the brain without the skull. This will be used to perform skull stripping. All voxels with the value greater than 0.5 (in the mask) are assumed to belong to the brain.

input.name: Atlasfile
input.description: This is the atlas specification file.

output.name: Output fmmparamfile
output.description: A file where the mixture parameters are written.

input.name: Unsigned
input.description: Specifying this option will assume that the data is unsigned.

input.name: Alpha
input.description: Parameter for blended crossover, defaults to 0.5.

input.name: Size
input.description: Population size, defaults to 100

input.name: Terminationthr
input.description: Threshold for terminating the algorithm, defaults to 0.0005

input.name: xoverrate
input.description: Crossover rate, defaults to 1

input.name: Maxgenerations
input.description: Maximum number of generations, defaults to 500

input.name: Sortpop
input.description: Whether to use the permutation operator, defaults to 1

input.name: Parzenn
input.description: Number of points for Parzen estimate (for approximate ML), defaults to 101

input.name: Parzensigma
input.description: Window width parameter for the Parzen estimate, defaults to 1.

input.name: Equalvar
input.description: Whether component densities should have equal variances, defaults to 0

input.name: Restarts
input.description: The number of individual runs of the GA, defaults to 10

module.name: MRI Convert
module.description: mri_convert is a general purpose utility for converting between different file formats. mri_convert will try to figure out the file format on its own from the format of the file name (eg, files that end in .img are assumed to be in spm analyze format).

input.name: Input Volume
input.description: The name of the input volume.

filetype.name: GDF file
filetype.description: GDF volume (requires image stem for output; use gis)

filetype.name: NIFTI1 file
filetype.description: NIfTI-1 volume (separate image and header files)

filetype.name: SPM file
filetype.description: SPM Analyze format (same as analyze and analyze3d)

input.name: Drop Frames
input.description: Drop the last <n> frames.

input.name: TE
input.description: TE in msec. Must specify <te>.

input.name: Output Info
input.description: Displays information about the output volume.

input.name: Crop
input.description: <x> <y> <z> Crop to 256 around center (x,y,z).

input.name: Output j Size
input.description: Specifies the output <j size>.

input.name: Zero GE z Offset
input.description: Sets c_s=0 (appropriate for DICOM files from GE machines with isocenter scanning).

input.name: Output Orientation Setting
input.description:
Supply the orientation information in the form of an orientation string (ostring). The ostring is three letters that roughly describe how the volume is oriented. This is usually described by the direction cosine information as originally derived from the dicom but might not be available in all data sets. You'll have to determine the correct ostring for your data.
The first character of ostring determines the direction of increasing column. The second character of ostring determines the direction of increasing row. The third character of ostring determines the direction of increasing slice.
e.g. If the volume is axial starting inferior and going superior the slice is oriented such that nose is pointing up and the right side of the subject is on the left side of the image, then this would correspond to LPS, i.e. as the column increases, you move to the patients left; as the row increases, you move posteriorly, and as the slice increases, you move superiorly. Valid letters are L, R, P, A, I, and S. There are 48 valid combinations (eg, RAS, LPI, SRI). Some invalid ones are DPS (D is not a valid letter), RRS (can't specify R twice), RAP (A and P refer to the same axis). Invalid combinations are detected immediately, an error printed, and the program exits. Case-insensitive.
Note: you can use tkregister2 to help determine the correct orientation string.

input.name: Unwarp Gradient Nonlinearity (Option 1)
input.description: Specifies option <sonata | allegra | GE> for unwarp gradient nonlinearity. Note: Must choose options 2-5 as well.

input.name: Output i Direction
input.description: Specifies the output i direction. Must specify <R direction>, <A direction> and <S direction>.

input.name: Output k Count
input.description: Specifies the output <k count>.

input.name: Resample Type
input.description: Specifies resample type. Must specify <interpolate|weighted|nearest|sinc|cubic>. (Default=interpolate)

input.name: TI
input.description: TI in msec (note uppercase flag). Must specify <ti>.

input.name: Force RAS Good
input.description: Uses default when orientation is absent.

input.name: Input Orientation Settings
input.description:
Supply the orientation information in the form of an orientation string (<ostring>). The <ostring> is three letters that roughly describe how the volume is oriented. This is usually described by the direction cosine information as originally derived from the dicom but might not be available in all data sets. You'll have to determine the correct ostring for your data.
The first character of ostring determines the direction of increasing column. The second character of ostring determines the direction of increasing row. The third character of ostring determines the direction of increasing slice.
e.g. If the volume is axial starting inferior and going superior the slice is oriented such that nose is pointing up and the right side of the subject is on the left side of the image, then this would correspond to LPS, i.e. as the column increases, you move to the patients left; as the row increases, you move posteriorly, and as the slice increases, you move superiorly. Valid letters are L, R, P, A, I, and S. There are 48 valid combinations (eg, RAS, LPI, SRI). Some invalid ones are DPS (D is not a valid letter), RRS (can't specify R twice), RAP (A and P refer to the same axis). Invalid combinations are detected immediately, an error printed, and the program exits. Case-insensitive.
Note: you can use tkregister2 to help determine the correct orientation string.

Conform to the src min direction size.

input.name: Input Type
input.description:
<type>
Legal values for --in_type (-it) and --out_type (-ot) are:
cor - MGH-NMR COR format (deprecated) mgh - MGH-NMR format mgz - MGH-NMR gzipped (compressed) mgh format minc - MNI's Medical Imaging NetCDF format (output may not work) analyze - 3D analyze (same as spm) analyze4d - 4D analyze spm - SPM Analyze format (same as analyze and analyze3d) ge - GE Genesis format (input only) gelx - GE LX (input only) lx - same as gelx ximg - GE XIMG variant (input only) siemens - Siemens IMA (input only) dicom - generic DICOM Format (input only) siemens_dicom - Siemens DICOM Format (input only) afni - AFNI format brik - same as afni bshort - MGH-NMR bshort format bfloat - MGH-NMR bfloat format sdt - Varian (?) outline - MGH-NMR Outline format otl - same as outline gdf - GDF volume (requires image stem for output; use -gis) nifti1 - NIfTI-1 volume (separate image and header files) nii - NIfTI-1 volume (single file) Note: if the input/output has extension .nii.gz, then compressed is used.
CONVERTING TO SPM-ANALYZE FORMAT
Converting to SPM-Analyze format can be done in two ways, depending upon whether a single frame or multiple frames are desired. For a single frame, simply specify the output file name with a .img extension, and mri_convert will save the first frame into the file. For multiple frames, specify the base as the output file name and add --out_type spm. This will save each frame as baseXXX.img where XXX is the three-digit, zero-padded frame number. Frame numbers begin at one. By default, the width the of zero padding is 3. This can be controlled with --in_nspmzeropad N where N is the new width.

input.description:
<type>

cor - MGH-NMR COR format (deprecated) mgh - MGH-NMR format mgz - MGH-NMR gzipped (compressed) mgh format minc - MNI's Medical Imaging NetCDF format (output may not work) analyze - 3D analyze (same as spm) analyze4d - 4D analyze spm - SPM Analyze format (same as analyze and analyze3d) ge - GE Genesis format (input only) gelx - GE LX (input only) lx - same as gelx ximg - GE XIMG variant (input only) siemens - Siemens IMA (input only) dicom - generic DICOM Format (input only) siemens_dicom - Siemens DICOM Format (input only) afni - AFNI format brik - same as afni bshort - MGH-NMR bshort format bfloat - MGH-NMR bfloat format sdt - Varian (?) outline - MGH-NMR Outline format otl - same as outline gdf - GDF volume (requires image stem for output; use -gis) nifti1 - NIfTI-1 volume (separate image and header files) nii - NIfTI-1 volume (single file) Note: if the input/output has extension .nii.gz, then compressed is used.
CONVERTING TO SPM-ANALYZE FORMAT
Converting to SPM-Analyze format can be done in two ways, depending upon whether a single frame or multiple frames are desired. For a single frame, simply specify the output file name with a .img extension, and mri_convert will save the first frame into the file. For multiple frames, specify the base as the output file name and add --out_type spm. This will save each frame as baseXXX.img where XXX is the three-digit, zero-padded frame number. Frame numbers begin at one. By default, the width the of zero padding is 3. This can be controlled with --in_nspmzeropad N where N is the new width.

module.name: MRI SegStats
module.description: This program will compute statistics on segmented volumes. In its simplest invocation, it will report on the number of voxels and volume in each segmentation. However, it can also compute statistics on the segmentation based on the values from another volume. This includes computing waveforms averaged inside each segmentation.

citations.citation:
Bruce Fischl, Martin I. Sereno and Anders M. Dale.Cortical Surface-Based Analysis II: Inflation, Flattening, and a Surface-Based Coordinate System. NeuroImage Volume 9, Issue 2, February 1999, Pages 195-207.
DOI: 10.1006/nimg.1998.0396

module.name: FSLMaths (nii.gz)
module.description: Simple but powerful program to allow mathematical manipulation of images.

S.M. Smith, M. Jenkinson, M.W. Woolrich, C.F. Beckmann, T.E.J. Behrens, H. Johansen-Berg, P.R. Bannister, M. De Luca, I. Drobnjak, D.E. Flitney, R. Niazy, J. Saunders, J. Vickers, Y. Zhang, N. De Stefano, J.M. Brady, and P.M. Matthews. Advances in functional and structural MR image analysis and implementation as FSL. NeuroImage, 23(S1):208-219, 2004
PMID: 15501092

input.name: Input File
input.description: Specifies the input file path.

input.name: Add (image)
input.description: Add following input (image) to current image.

input.name: Subtract (integer)
input.description: Subtract following input (integer) from current image.

input.name: Subtract (image)
input.description: Subtract following input (image) from current image.

input.name: Multiply (integer)
input.description: Multiply current image by following input (integer).

input.name: Multiply (image)
input.description: Multiply current image by following input (image).

input.name: Divide (integer)
input.description: Divide current image by following input (integer).

input.name: Divide (image)
input.description: Divide current image by following input (image).

input.name: Mask
input.description: Use (following image>0) to mask current image.

input.name: Threshold
input.description: Use following number to threshold current image (zero anything below the number).

input.name: Upper-Threshold
input.description: Use following number to upper-threshold current image (zero anything above the number).

input.name: Max (integer)
input.description: Take maximum of following input (integer) and current image.

input.name: Max (image)
input.description: Take maximum of following input (image) and current image.

input.name: Min (integer)
input.description: Take minimum of following input (integer) and current image.

input.name: Min (image)
input.description: Take minimum of following input (image) and current image.

input.name: Exponential
input.description: Exponential unary operation.

input.name: Natural logarithm
input.description: Natural logarithm unary operation.

input.name: Square
input.description: Square unary operation.

input.name: Square root
input.description: Square root unary operation.

input.name: Absolute Value
input.description: Absolute value unary operation.

input.name: Binarise
input.description: Use (current image>0) to binarise.

input.name: Edge
input.description: Edge strength.

input.name: Replace NaN
input.description: Replace NaNs (improper numbers) with 0.

input.name: Make NaN
input.description: Make NaN (improper number) mask with 1 for NaN voxels, 0 otherwise.

input.name: X Mean
input.description: Mean across x dimension.

input.name: Y Mean
input.description: Mean across y dimension.

input.name: Z Mean
input.description: Mean across z dimension.

input.name: T Mean
input.description: Mean across time.

input.name: X Std Dev
input.description: Standard deviation across x dimension.

input.name: Y Std Dev
input.description: Standard deviation across y dimension.

input.name: Z Std Dev
input.description: Standard deviation across z dimension.

input.name: T Std Dev
input.description: Standard deviation across time.

input.name: X Max
input.description: Maximum across x dimension.

input.name: Y Max
input.description: Maximum across y dimension.

input.name: Z Max
input.description: Maximum across z dimension.

input.name: T Max
input.description: Maximum across time.

input.name: X Max Index
input.description: X index of max across x dimension.

input.name: Y Max Index
input.description: Y index of max across y dimension.

input.name: Z Max Index
input.description: Z index of max across z dimension.

input.name: T Max Index
input.description: Time index of max across time.

input.name: X Min
input.description: Minimum across x dimension.

input.name: Z Min
input.description: Minimum across z dimension.

input.name: T Min
input.description: Minimum across time.

input.name: X Median
input.description: Median across x dimension.

input.name: Y Median
input.description: Median across y dimension.

input.name: Z Median
input.description: Median across z dimension.

input.name: T Median
input.description: Median across time.

input.name: X Percentage
input.description: <n>th percentile (0-100) across x dimension.

input.name: Y Percentage
input.description: <n>th percentile (0-100) across y dimension.

input.name: Z Percentage
input.description: <n>th percentile (0-100) across z dimension.

input.name: T Percentage
input.description: <n>th percentile (0-100) across time.

input.name: X AR Coefficient
input.description: AR Coefficient across x dimension.

input.name: Y AR Coefficient
input.description: AR Coefficient across y dimension.

input.name: Z AR Coefficient
input.description: AR Coefficient across z dimension.

input.name: T AR Coefficient
input.description: Temporal AR(1) coefficient (use _32R and probably demean first).

input.name: Remainder (integer)
input.description: Modulus remainder - divide current integer by following input and take remainder.

input.name: Remainder (image)
input.description: Modulus remainder - divide current image by following input and take remainder.

input.name: Threshold Percentage
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE to threshold current image (zero anything below the number).

input.name: Threshold Percentage (non-zero voxels)
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE of non-zero voxels and threshold below.

input.name: Upper-Threshold Percentage
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE to upper-threshold current image (zero anything above the number).

input.name: Upper-Threshold Percentage (non-zero voxels)
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE of non-zero voxels and threshold above.

input.name: Index
input.description: Replace each nonzero voxel with a unique (subject to wrapping) index number.

input.name: Grid
input.description: Add a 3D grid of intensity <value> with grid spacing <spacing>. Usage: -grid <value> <spacing>

input.name: TFCE
input.description: Enhance with TFCE, e.g. -tfce 2 0.5 6 (maybe change 6 to 26 for skeletons). Usage: -tfce <H> <E> <connectivity>

input.name: Intensity Normalisation (per 3D volume mean)
input.description: (-i i ip.c) intensity normalisation (per 3D volume mean). Usage: -inm <mean>

input.name: Intensity Normalisation (global 4D mean)
input.description: (-I i ip.c) intensity normalisation, global 4D mean). Usage: -ing <mean>

input.name: Kernel 3D
input.description: 3x3x3 box centered on target voxel (set as default kernel).

input.name: Kernel 2D
input.description: 3x3x1 box centered on target voxel.

input.name: Kernel Box
input.description: All voxels in a box of width <size> centered on target voxel. Usage: -kernel box <size>

input.name: Kernel BoxV
input.description: <size>x<size>x<size> box centered on target voxel. CAUTION: size should be an odd number. Usage: -kernel boxv <size>

input.name: Kernel Gauss
input.description: Gaussian kernel (sigma in mm, not voxels). Usage: -kernel gauss <sigma>

input.name: Kernel Sphere
input.description: All voxels in a sphere of radius <size> mm centered on target voxel. Usage: -kernel sphere <size>

input.name: Kernel File
input.description: Use external file as kernel. Usage: -kernel file <filename>

input.name: Mean Dilation
input.description: Mean Dilation of zero voxels (using non-zero voxels in kernel).

input.name: Modal Dilation
input.description: Modal Dilation of zero voxels (using non-zero voxels in kernel).

input.name: Maximum Filtering
input.description: Maximum filtering of all voxels.

input.name: Erode
input.description: Erode by zeroing non-zero voxels when zero voxels found in kernel.

input.name: Minimum Filtering
input.description: Minimum filtering of all voxels.

input.name: Median Filtering
input.description: Median filtering.

input.name: Mean Filtering
input.description: Mean filtering, kernel weighted (conventionally used with gauss kernel).

input.name: Mean Filtering (un-normalised)
input.description: Mean filtering, kernel weighted, un-normalised (gives edge effects).

input.name: Sigma
input.description: Create a gauss kernel of sigma mm and perform mean filtering. Usage: -s <sigma>

input.name: Downsample Image (centered)
input.description: Downsamples image by a factor of 2 (keeping new voxels centred on old).

input.name: Downsample Image (non-centered)
input.description: Downsamples image by a factor of 2 (non-centred).

input.name: Region of Interest
input.description: Zero outside ROI. Usage: -roi <xmin> <xsize> <ymin> <ysize> <zmin> <zsize> <tmin> <tsize>

input.name: BPTF
input.description: (-t in ip.c) Bandpass temporal filtering; nonlinear highpass and Gaussian linear lowpass (with sigmas in volumes, not seconds); set either sigma<0 to skip that filter. Usage: -bptf <hp_sigma> <lp_sigma>

input.name: ROC
input.description: Take (normally binary) truth and test current image in ROC analysis against truth. <AROC-thresh> is usually 0.05 and is limit of Area-under-ROC measure FP axis. <outfile> is a text file of the ROC curve (triplets of values: FP TP threshold). If the truth image contains negative voxels these get excluded from all calculations. If <AROC-thresh> is positive then the [4Dnoiseonly] option needs to be set, and the FP rate is determined from this noise-only data, and is set to be the fraction of timepoints where any FP (anywhere) is seen, as found in the noise-only 4d-dataset. This is then controlling the FWE rate. If <AROC-thresh> is negative the FP rate is calculated from the zero-value parts of the <truth> image, this time averaging voxelwise FP rate over all timepoints. In both cases the TP rate is the average fraction of truth=positive voxels correctly found. Usage: -roc <AROC-thresh> <outfile> [4dnoiseonly] <truth>

input.name: 4D Noise Only
input.description: Option for ROC. If <AROC-thresh> is positive then the [4Dnoiseonly] option needs to be set.

input.name: AROC-thresh
input.description: Option for ROC. <AROC-thresh> is usually 0.05 and is limit of Area-under-ROC measure FP axis.

input.name: Truth
input.description: Option for ROC. If <AROC-thresh> is negative the FP rate is calculated from the zero-value parts of the <truth> image, this time averaging voxelwise FP rate over all timepoints.

input.name: Outfile
input.description: Option for ROC. <outfile> is a text file of the ROC curve (triplets of values: FP TP threshold).

input.name: Y Min
input.description: Minimum across y dimension.

input.name: Add (integer)
input.description: Add following input (integer) to current image.

input.description: Take (normally binary) truth and test current image in ROC analysis against truth. <AROC-thresh> is usually 0.05 and is limit of Area-under-ROC measure FP axis. <outfile> is a text file of the ROC curve (triplets of values: FP TP threshold). If the truth image contains negative voxels these get excluded from all calculations. If <AROC-thresh> is positive then the [4Dnoiseonly] option needs to be set, and the FP rate is determined from this noise-only data, and is set to be the fraction of timepoints where any FP (anywhere) is seen, as found in the noise-only 4d-dataset. This is then controlling the FWE rate. If <AROC-thresh> is negative the FP rate is calculated from the zero-value parts of the <truth> image, this time averaging voxelwise FP rate over all timepoints. In both cases the TP rate is the average fraction of truth=positive voxels correctly found. Usage: -roc <AROC-thresh> <outfile> [4dnoiseonly] <truth>

input.name: 4D Noise Only
input.description: Option for ROC. If <AROC-thresh> is positive then the [4Dnoiseonly] option needs to be set.

input.name: AROC-thresh
input.description: Option for ROC. <AROC-thresh> is usually 0.05 and is limit of Area-under-ROC measure FP axis.

input.name: Truth
input.description: Option for ROC. If <AROC-thresh> is negative the FP rate is calculated from the zero-value parts of the <truth> image, this time averaging voxelwise FP rate over all timepoints.

input.name: Outfile
input.description: Option for ROC. <outfile> is a text file of the ROC curve (triplets of values: FP TP threshold).

input.name: Y Min
input.description: Minimum across y dimension.

input.name: Add (integer)
input.description: Add following input (integer) to current image.

input.description: Make NaN (improper number) mask with 1 for NaN voxels, 0 otherwise.

input.description: Standard deviation across time.

input.description: Maximum across x dimension.

input.description: Maximum across y dimension.

input.description: Maximum across z dimension.

input.name: T Max
input.description: Maximum across time.

input.name: Y Max Index
input.description: Y index of max across y dimension.

input.description: Minimum across z dimension.

input.description: Minimum across time.

input.description: Median across x dimension.

input.description: AR Coefficient across x dimension.

input.description: Modulus remainder - divide current integer by following input and take remainder.

input.name: Remainder (image)
input.description: Modulus remainder - divide current image by following input and take remainder.

input.name: Threshold Percentage
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE to threshold current image (zero anything below the number).

input.name: Threshold Percentage (non-zero voxels)
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE of non-zero voxels and threshold below.

input.name: Upper-Threshold Percentage
input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE to upper-threshold current image (zero anything above the number).

input.description: Use following percentage (0-100) of ROBUST RANGE of non-zero voxels and threshold above.

input.name: Index
input.description: Replace each nonzero voxel with a unique (subject to wrapping) index number.

input.name: Grid
input.description: Add a 3D grid of intensity <value> with grid spacing <spacing>. Usage: -grid <value> <spacing>

input.name: TFCE
input.description: Enhance with TFCE, e.g. -tfce 2 0.5 6 (maybe change 6 to 26 for skeletons). Usage: -tfce <H> <E> <connectivity>

input.name: Intensity Normalisation (per 3D volume mean)
input.description: (-i i ip.c) intensity normalisation (per 3D volume mean). Usage: -inm <mean>

input.name: Intensity Normalisation (global 4D mean)
input.description: (-I i ip.c) intensity normalisation, global 4D mean). Usage: -ing <mean>

input.name: Kernel 3D
input.description: 3x3x3 box centered on target voxel (set as default kernel).

input.name: Kernel 2D
input.description: 3x3x1 box centered on target voxel.

input.name: Kernel Box
input.description: All voxels in a box of width <size> centered on target voxel. Usage: -kernel box <size>

input.name: Kernel BoxV
input.description: <size>x<size>x<size> box centered on target voxel. CAUTION: size should be an odd number. Usage: -kernel boxv <size>

input.name: Kernel Gauss
input.description: Gaussian kernel (sigma in mm, not voxels). Usage: -kernel gauss <sigma>

input.name: Kernel Sphere
input.description: All voxels in a sphere of radius <size> mm centered on target voxel. Usage: -kernel sphere <size>

input.name: Kernel File
input.description: Use external file as kernel. Usage: -kernel file <filename>

input.name: Mean Dilation
input.description: Mean Dilation of zero voxels (using non-zero voxels in kernel).

input.name: Modal Dilation
input.description: Modal Dilation of zero voxels (using non-zero voxels in kernel).

input.name: Maximum Filtering
input.description: Maximum filtering of all voxels.

input.name: Erode
input.description: Erode by zeroing non-zero voxels when zero voxels found in kernel.

input.name: Minimum Filtering
input.description: Minimum filtering of all voxels.

input.name: Median Filtering
input.description: Median filtering.

input.name: Mean Filtering
input.description: Mean filtering, kernel weighted (conventionally used with gauss kernel).

input.name: Mean Filtering (un-normalised)
input.description: Mean filtering, kernel weighted, un-normalised (gives edge effects).

input.name: Sigma
input.description: Create a gauss kernel of sigma mm and perform mean filtering. Usage: -s <sigma>

input.name: Downsample Image (centered)
input.description: Downsamples image by a factor of 2 (keeping new voxels centred on old).

input.name: Downsample Image (non-centered)
input.description: Downsamples image by a factor of 2 (non-centred).

input.name: Region of Interest
input.description: Zero outside ROI. Usage: -roi <xmin> <xsize> <ymin> <ysize> <zmin> <zsize> <tmin> <tsize>

input.name: BPTF
input.description: (-t in ip.c) Bandpass temporal filtering; nonlinear highpass and Gaussian linear lowpass (with sigmas in volumes, not seconds); set either sigma<0 to skip that filter. Usage: -bptf <hp_sigma> <lp_sigma>
